item.title: A Medieval DSL? Parsing Heraldic Blazons with Python
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Lady Red

Track:PyConDE Medieval people invented one of the first domain specific languages to describe how to paint Coats of Arms. We'll learn how to write our own parse grammar to parse this language, and then look at the parse grammar of Python itself!

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/EE33M8 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Lady Red

item.title: Abridged metaprogramming classics - this episode: pytest
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Oliver Bestwalter

Track:PyConDE This talk is not about how to use pytest. pytest is a good project to explore metaprogramming techniques like introspection and code as data in the context of solving real world problems.

In this case: implementing a test framework.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/XTD7TE Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Oliver Bestwalter

item.title: Driving 3D Printers with Python: Lessons Learned
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Gina Häußge

Track:PyConDE OctoPrint is an open source web interface for 3D printers and deployed world wide on a large variety of devices. In this talk I explain some of the challenges in developing and maintaining such a piece of end user facing software in Python.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/JQAUEC Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Gina Häußge

item.title: Event-Sourced Story
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Jacek Kołodziej

Track:PyConDE After three years of utilizing event sourcing in [Growbots](http://growbots.com), I want to introduce to you its basics and share our experience acquired over that time - including complexity involved - so you can better assess whether it's a tool wo

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/SXSE8D Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Jacek Kołodziej

item.title: Introduction to automated testing with pytest
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Raphael Pierzina

Track:PyConDE We'll learn how to get started with developing automated tests in Python with the [pytest] test framework.

[pytest]: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/3JUWNC Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Raphael Pierzina

item.title: Monitoring infrastructure and application using Django, Sensu and Celery.
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Hari Kishore Sirivella

Track:PyConDE Monitoring is a key aspect for any business. It enables us to find and be notified about our application's problems way ahead our customer notices it, which enables us to keep our businesses running and making customers happy.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/LWALGX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Hari Kishore Sirivella

item.title: Optimizing Input: Building your own customized keyboard
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Daniel Rios

Track:PyConDE Keyboards, the main way we interact with computers, have remained unchanged for a century, despite being free from mechanical necessity. Alternatives made possible by recent technology can optimize the way we input text and interact with our devices.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WJGCNV Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Daniel Rios

item.title: Parallel programming for python developers – Let’s Go(lang)
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Dominik Henter, Jéssica Lins

Track:PyConDE Despite all of python's strengths, parallel programming tends to not be one of them. Enter Go, a language that has parallel programming at its core. In this tutorial we will build an API pipeline service in Go, that calls several APIs in parallel.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/9AKC3R Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Dominik Henter

item.title: Strawberry: a dataclasses inspired approach to GraphQL
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Patrick Arminio

Over the past few years, GraphQL has gained much traction, especially in the JavaScript world. Python is getting on board this trend with new interesting libraries. In this talk, we will see how Strawberry makes uses of dataclasses and type hints to

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/QABWWM Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Patrick Arminio

item.title: What we learned from scraping 1 billion webpages every month
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Samet Atdag

Web is broken. We learned the hard way. Developers tend to hack, hacks tend to break the web. In this talk, I share what we learned how websites don't obey the protocols and how developers had caused the web became a chaotic medium.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/Q88ZUW Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Samet Atdag

item.title: What’s new in Python 3.8?
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Stéphane Wirtel

In few months, there will be the release of Python 3.8! As a core dev I would like to show you the new features of this version.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/CATV3T Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Stéphane Wirtel

item.title: 10 ways to debug Python code
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Christoph Deil

Track:PyConDE Are your debugging skills limited to "print", or do you sometimes think there must be a better way to figure out what's going on? I will show 10 ways to debug Python code, and share tips and tricks for effective debugging.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/TRFD98 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Christoph Deil

item.title: 6 Years of Docker: The Good, the Bad and Python Packaging
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Sebastian Neubauer

Track:PyConDE Local development of python code inside a docker container is surprisingly broken. In this talk I will walk you through the proper setup of a local python development environment using docker.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/A7FWAW Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Neubauer

item.title: Beyond Paradigms: a new key to grok Python & other languages
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Luciano Ramalho

Track:PyConDE Focus on features, not paradigms. This new approach to the study of programming languages offers practical advice for programmers learning a new language, adopting coding idioms, and choosing suitable design patterns.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/QCNNTW Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Luciano Ramalho

item.title: Break your API gently - or not at all
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Tim Hoffmann

Track:PyConDE As hard as we try to write good code, there will always be cases in which we wish we had designed a different function signature, chosen another attribute name, ... But you can't change it anymore because it's public API - or can you?

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/QXB8DR Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Tim Hoffmann

item.title: Chips Made From Python
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Dan Fritchman

Track:PyConDE Introduction to Python hardware description libraries, and how they are being used to design modern silicon, including open-source RISC-V CPUs.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WURZX8 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Dan Fritchman

item.title: Commenting code — beyond common wisdom
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Stefan Schwarzer

Track:PyConDE Good code comments are important for software maintenance. This talk goes beyond the common wisdom you find in most books and online and explains when this common wisdom falls short.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/SUC9VW Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Stefan Schwarzer

item.title: Docker and Python - A Match made in Heaven
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Dr. Hendrik Niemeyer

Track:PyConDE Containers have revolutionized the way we build and ship software. This talk is aimed at newcomers and people with limited experience with Docker and will cover the basics of Docker and how it can be used alongside Python.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/VERUFX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Dr. Hendrik Niemeyer

item.title: Dr. Schmood's Notebook of Python Calisthenics and Orthodontia
item.description:
Description

Speaker: David Schmudde

Track:PyConDE Explore the benefits of taking a functional approach when writing Python in Jupyter notebooks: reduce errors caused by out-of-order execution and hidden state while producing more readable code.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/F3TCZN Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: David Schmudde

item.title: From body and code programming in times of acceptance
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Paloma

Track:PyConDE This talk is meant to bring awareness about the need of diversity from theoretical to practical day by day actions. Diversity not only as social justice, but to reclaim knowledge proficiency, critical perspective and new ideas.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/FQMFKX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Paloma

item.title: Getting started with FPGA with Python
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Olga

Track:PyConDE In this review, we'll look into frameworks that will help Python developer start working with FPGA without prior knowledge of Verilog or VHDL.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/PHYCJL Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Olga

item.title: Is it me, or the GIL?
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Christoph Heer

Track:PyConDE People refer Python's Global Interpreter Lock as main bottleneck for their performance critical applications. But how can you test if your application really suffer from the GIL?

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/BHDEAR Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Christoph Heer

item.title: Keynote: Python 2020+ - Lukas Langa
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Łukasz Langa

While very successful, Python's peculiarly missing in some spaces like mobile devices, client-side Web, or gaming. Should we do something about it? How could we go about changing that?

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/JFNCMQ Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Łukasz Langa

item.title: Static Typing in Python
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Dustin Ingram

In this talk, we'll discuss the advantages and disadvantages to a static type system, as well as recent efforts to introduce static typing to Python via optional "type hints" and various tools to aid in adding types to Python code.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/NH9UEY Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Dustin Ingram

item.title: Tutorial: An Introduction to Concurrency and Parallelism using Python Programming Language
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Tanmoy Bandyopadhyay

Track:PyConDE Python concurrency and parallelism concepts like Multiprocessing, Multithreading, Coroutine, Asynchronous I/O will be explained. We will learn to write simpler code with improved response time and throughput.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/SC7JGK Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Tanmoy Bandyopadhyay

item.title: Tutorial: Kubernetes 101 for Python Developers
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Christian Barra

Track:PyConDE Kubernetes (K8s) is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

During this training you will learn how to use it and how it can help as a Python developer.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/D8VAN9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Christian Barra

item.title: venv, pyenv, pypi, pip, pipenv, pyWTF?
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Simone Robutti

The ecosystem of Python tooling is fragmented, confusing, full of quirks and therefore hostile to newcomers and veterans alike. Let's try to make sense of it.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/HQJMTL Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Simone Robutti

item.title: What if I tell you that your specs are broken
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Samuele Maci

This talk is going to be about Swagger Specs and their changes. We're going to examine what Backward Incompatible changes are and how you can deal with them. The talk will also introduce you to a tool that will help you on having safer changes.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/NFH83Z Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Samuele Maci

item.title: Boosting simulation performance with Python
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Eran Friedman

Track:PyConDE In this talk I will present the architecture of our simulation (written in Python) which allows us to simulate hours of real-life in only minutes of simulation. I will describe challenges we encountered and how we handled them.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/CEYMMK Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Eran Friedman

item.title: Developers vs. Enterprise
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Ingo Stegmaier

Track:PyConDE This 30-minute talk will give you an overview about project management, success factors and specialties within enterprises. This will be a guide how you promote internal projects and bring them to success within a highly "political" environment.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/XJLSWG Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Ingo Stegmaier

item.title: How MicroPython went into space
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Christine Spindler

Track:PyConDE MicroPython is a lean and efficient implementation of the Python 3 programming language, optimised to run on microcontrollers and in constrained environments. One of these environments is on a spacecraft.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/7QRAWK Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Christine Spindler

item.title: Keynote: PEP 581 and PEP 588: Migrating CPython's Issue Tracker - Mariatta Wijaya
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Mariatta Wijaya

Track:PyConDE The acceptance of PEP 581, by Python steering council means that another big workflow change is impending. Let's hear about some of the proposed plans on improving CPython's workflow, and learn how you can help and take part in this process.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/DFCU3K Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Mariatta Wijaya

item.title: Mock Hell
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Edwin Jung

Track:PyConDE Mock is an easily abused tool. In perverse cases, it increases technical debt and prevents refactoring. This talk describes the history of mocking, alternatives, anti-patterns, and the connection to clean architecture.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/NZC3A8 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Edwin Jung

item.title: pytest - simple, rapid and fun testing with Python
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Florian Bruhin

The pytest tool presents a rapid and simple way to write tests for your Python code. This training gives an introduction with exercises to some distinguishing features.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WRHHSF Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Florian Bruhin

item.title: Refactoring in Python: Design Patterns and Approaches
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Tin Marković

Experiences and lessons learned from tackling extremely demanding code. How to bring order to mismanaged code and elevate the code base to a standard that's acceptable in today's tech environment.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/FTVNPK Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Tin Marković

item.title: Running An Open Source Project Like A Start Up
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Cheuk Ting Ho

Not so long ago, I started an open source project - PicknMIx. It feels like running a start up if you are serious about it. Want to know my story? Want to check if you can do it as well? I will tell you. (Stickers not guaranteed though)

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/9ARCJA Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Cheuk Ting Ho

item.title: Tutorial: Package and Dependency Management with Poetry
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Steph Samson

Track:PyConDE Poetry is “Python packaging and dependency management made easy.”It not only packages up your libraries easily but also isolates environments and resolves dependencies — all with an intuitive command line interface.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/CFPRJ8 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Steph Samson

item.title: Tutorial: Write your Own Decorators
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Mike Müller

Decorators are really useful. Using them is simple. Writing your own is bit more involved. Learn in this hands-on workshop how to write decorators for many different purposes. The emphasis is on best practices and practical examples.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ASLHQN Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Mike Müller

item.title: Using Micropython to develop an IoT multimode sensor platform with an Augmented Reality UI
item.description:
Description

Speaker: Nicholas Herriot

Building a sensor platform that is flexible and intuitive is hard! This talk takes you through a journey how a sensor platform was developed to create a sensor farm for the purpose of capturing and acquiring data to be used in AI systems for Samsung.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/7X799R Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin, https://twitter.com/pyconde
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Herriot
